admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Paiton Thermal Power
            Project for Indonesia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was likely, Bank
            performance was highly satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also highly satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: International Competitive Bidding (ICB) is
            the best means to ensure low prices. Contract costs awarded
            through ICB have been lower than their estimated costs,
            while costs of contracts awarded through direct negotiations
            under Co-financing have been significantly higher than their
            estimated costs. The practice of conducting long and
            protracted negotiations with the winning bidder to drive
            down quoted prices, or increase the local content, may
            appear to be an accomplishment in the short-term. However,
            it may not be in the best interests of PLN (Engineering
            Services Center) as the contractor could run short of
            resources to sustain its operations and deliver in
            accordance with the agreed schedule, as is clearly borne out
            by the experience gained on this project. Bank policy
            dialogue should be linked to individual projects. In this
            case, while the Bank raised the problem of excess capacity
            as early as 1994, a stronger case could have been made if
            the implication of this excess capacity for Bank financed
            plants such as Paiton had been highlighted at an earlier stage.
